articles.headline: Hybrid Model for Nonprofits Hits Snags
articles.snippet: Dual-mission companies try to address the financing difficulties faced by many nonprofit groups. But sometimes the business unit falters and cannot support the nonprofit.
articles.abstract: Dual-mission companies try to address the financing difficulties faced by many nonprofit groups. But sometimes the business unit falters and cannot support the nonprofit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 2003, the GlobalGiving Foundation has used its Web site to channel more than $30 million to charitable projects like buying seeds for farmers in Zimbabwe and feeding orphaned chimpanzees.

articles.headline: Riches May Not Help Papua New Guinea
articles.snippet: An expected flood of money in Papua New Guinea could throw a country already beset by corruption into further turmoil.
articles.abstract: An expected flood of money in Papua New Guinea could throw a country already beset by corruption into further turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: TARI, Papua New Guinea  A founding myth in the Southern Highlands of Papua New Guinea is said to have foretold the arrival of ExxonMobil, the American oil giant that is preparing to extract natural gas here and ship it overseas.

articles.headline: In Bond Frenzy, Investors Bet on Inflation
articles.snippet: Investors are betting that inflation will rise to a level that more than compensates for the premium they paid initially for five-year Treasuries.
articles.abstract: Investors are betting that inflation will rise to a level that more than compensates for the premium they paid initially for five-year Treasuries.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when savers complain that they are earning almost no interest from their bank accounts, some investors on Monday bought United States government bonds that effectively had a negative rate of return.

articles.headline: Chinese Telecom Giant in Push for U.S. Market
articles.snippet: Security concerns make telecommunications a particularly delicate industry in the United States.
articles.abstract: Security concerns make telecommunications a particularly delicate industry in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  This spring, an executive from a Chinese telecommunications equipment company made an intriguing job offer to a Silicon Valley software engineer. The Chinese company, Huawei Technologies, wanted to get into the booming market for Internet-based computing, and it had just moved its United States research headquarters here to capture some of the best local talent.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and David Barboza

articles.headline: A Labor Issue Ensnares ‘The Hobbit’
articles.snippet: Filming had been threatened by a dispute over whether a New Zealand branch of an Australian union could engage in collective bargaining on their Hollywood films.
articles.abstract: Filming had been threatened by a dispute over whether a New Zealand branch of an Australian union could engage in collective bargaining on their Hollywood films.

articles.headline: Deficit Divisions Likely to Grow After Election
articles.snippet: A midterm campaign that has turned heavily on the issue of mounting federal debt is likely to yield a government even more split over how to handle it.
articles.abstract: A midterm campaign that has turned heavily on the issue of mounting federal debt is likely to yield a government even more split over how to handle it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A midterm campaign that has turned heavily on the issue of the mounting federal debt is likely to yield a government even more split over what to do about it, people in both parties say, with diminished Democrats and reinforced Republicans confronting internal divisions even as they dig in against the other side.

articles.headline: Treasury Hid A.I.G. Loss, Report Says
articles.snippet: In early October, the Treasury estimated that taxpayers would lose $5 billion on their investment in A.I.G., in contrast with a earlier prediction of $45 billion.
articles.abstract: In early October, the Treasury estimated that taxpayers would lose $5 billion on their investment in A.I.G., in contrast with a earlier prediction of $45 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States Treasury concealed $40 billion in likely taxpayer losses on the bailout of the American International Group earlier this month, when it abandoned its usual method for valuing investments, according to a report by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program.

articles.headline: Ford Posts 6th Quarter of Profit in a Row
articles.snippet: The automaker earned $1.7 billion and said it expected to have zero net debt by the end of December.
articles.abstract: The automaker earned $1.7 billion and said it expected to have zero net debt by the end of December.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  A surge in third-quarter profit is the best evidence yet that the Ford Motor Company has moved into a period of sustained growth  further distinguishing itself from rivals despite a weak economy and slack overall demand.
